column11: Review Text

Buddhist religious site with influence of Hinduism culture. The significant sights at this site are the impressive rock carvings which include the famous moonstone of semicircular shape carvings at the foot of first flight of step at the staircase and the guarding gods carvings at the entrance. It is included in the entrance fee of USD25 for the Polonnaruwa Ancient site. Well worth the value as part of the UNESCO World Heritage.
I hadn't heard about this place before I went but so glad it was part of the escorted tour.  Fascinating place to visit.

Sinhalese architecture was known for its moonstones, semi-circular stone slabs often found at the bottom of staircases and entrances. Those at Polonnawura were a bit different. One band of animals became three [lion, elephant and horse]. They were not only placed at the entrances of Buddhist temples. That at the northern entrance of the Vatadage is the best surviving specimen at this site.
The architectural constructs, and the debriefs, are enlightening - you get to understand the deeper meaning of rituals

Moon stone is one of the greatest creations of ancient Sri Lanka. The images indicate the very truth of life. From birth till death , the difference stages of life has been depicted. The most obvious difference you can identify between the Moonstone of ANuradhapura Era & Polonnaruwa is the image of cow. In Anuradhapura Era , the moonstone has the image of cow. However with the Hindu influence during the time of Polonnaruwa, it was thought to be a disrespect to have the image of the cow on a place where people will shrug their legs. Cow was considered a holistic animal in India & that influenced the Art & craft of Polonnaruwa.

It's easy to ignore history at ground level  when confronted with a variety of structures, temples, stupas, etc. These moonstones are a unique feature of the Sinhalese architecture of ancient Sri Lanka. They are elaborately carved semi-circular stone slabs that are placed at the bottom of staircases and entrances. The challenge is now preservation and protection from the tourist hordes that walk on them.

while we are doing Polonnaruwa ancient city tour,we saw this stone creation,worth to know about history,there was one reduction when considering with Anuradhapura kingdom moonstone,because hinduism affected during the Polonnaruwa kingdom,so the pic of  bull has been removed in this moonstone,very old creation,but still can see the animals created in the stone,really very nice history,very interesting

This intricately carved stone can be found sitting at the entrance of the temples within Polonnaruwa, complex. the carvings symbolise the cycle of Saṃsāra (the never ending cycle of repeated birth) in Buddhism.
The stone is well preserved with relatively clear carvings considering its age and treatment it received over the past few centuries.
At the bottom of steps to religious areas you'll find a moonstone. Some of them have been smoothed by time and the passing of many feet. Some of them are still very intricately carved. Beautiful

Sandakada Pahana roughly translates as "moonstone" and it actually is a half-circle shaped stone, covered with eight bands of delicate animal (elephant, bull, lion and horse) and floral carvings. You can find great examples of it in both Annuradhapura and Polonnaruwa. It seems to be a very popular architectural motif and you will find it in front of many old and new buildings, all over the island.

Sandakada Pahana are the Moon stones, which are invariably found on the floor, at the entrance of important Buddhist structure from the ancient kingdom's time. The Moon stones are beautifully carved depicting various designs, which has a uniqueness to it. Looking at Moon stones, experts can interpret, to which kingdom and era they as well as the structure, belongs to.

These hand carved, Moonstones feature at the base of steps on many of various attractions all around Polonnaruwa .so make sure to keep you head down and keep an eye for them. the one in Polonnaruwa is the most famous and the most frequented.. It would be better if you have a travel guide so you could learn this in details .

Sandakada Pahana or would say moon-stone can be seen through Kindom of anuradhapura ,polonnaruwa and till the last Kindom kandy.According to mahawansaya it symbolize the "sansara" in buddhism .How ever the architecture and craftsmanship is superb ,We can see different types of animals and carvings in different places

Four women related but of different ages toured Sri Lanka for two weeks to study Buddhist art and culture.  This was first intro to the moonstone carving and found it fascinating.  I actually commissioned a moonstone batik that is king size bed size.  It is being shipped.
Excellent ancient archiological constructions. There are some differences with the anuradhapura moonstone

Start from the museum to understand all about moon stone as they have dedicated space for this. You would have to admire the work done on these moon stones as they are hand carved. They feature at various attractions all around Polonnaruwa, so make sure to keep you head down and keep an eye for them.
This is pretty looking old moonstone here.A quite popular place with the locals.You must see.You need about half an hour.

The moonstone o Polonnaruwa differs from that of the Anuradhapura temples. This is the stone structure seen at the base of the steps of the temples. In this moonstone each circle has one animal depiction of the circle of life.

Situated within the main polonnaruwa ruins. It would be ideal if you visit this place having the background history knowledge. Evening visit more convenient because of the warm weather. There are variations to the Anuradhapura Sadakada Pahana.

One can see these beautiful moonstones at the bottom of steps leading up to buddhist buildings. It is a semi circular piece of ornately decorated stone and a unique feature of Sinhalese architecture. Great for photography.

Sandakada Pahana are elaborately carved moon shaped stones that sit at the base of steps and are apparently a feature of various ancient sites in Sri Lanka. The most famous and the ones seen were in Polnnaruwa Vatadage. There were a number of these in the ancient ruins which  were a must see if in Sri Lanka.
I heard about Moonstones a dozen times when I was in SL. This one is truly an interesting one. The intricate details carved on this stone is one that should be seen for anyone visiting SL

Another amazing site and a must visit if you are here to see the ruins. Imagine the weight of this rick imagine trying to carve just intricate detail into it. This alone creates great introspection into the capabilities of our society today.

This intricately carved moonstone is found at the northern entrance to the Vadatage which is in the 'quadrangle' section of Polonnaruwa. We've seen many moonstones on our independent tour of Sri Lanka (including at Anuradhapura) but this is certainly one of the most impressive.
Found at the entrance of most temples along with Guardstones the different rings (getting smaller) have a different meaning.

This is the best protected specimen of Sandakada Pahana  (The stepping stone) found in Polonnaruwa. The main difference  of this and the specimen you can see at Anuradhapura is that the oxen is not depicted in this one. This is due to increased influence of Hinduism at the time of creation of the masterpiece. The ancients believed and we still  believe and try to to study and understand the cycle of life and the cause of it so we can end the unending cycle of suffering(life) and break it for one and all(Nibbana ) This stone depicts various stages of the path to end of suffering with and artistic elegance. Take time to study it and use the plaque placed at the site by the archaeological department to understand the underlying meaning which will be good for the soul.

These are moonstones that you will see in Polonnaruwa. They are like a mat where kings used to clean their feet before entering. They are beautifully carved and have a meaning to the design. I was really fascinated by them. You will find people selling souvenir of moonstone too.
One of the most wonderful creations in Sri Lankan history. Pollonnaruwa sandakada pahana is different from Anuradhapura sandakada Pahana.
I agree with the TA reviews below... not just a piece of stone.. every layer has a meaning and is preserved beautifully.. Definitely a 'must see' and is in much better condition than Anuradhapura...

This elaborately carved moonstone represents the Buddhist philosophy that guides kelt explaining was nit a religion as such. Even to those of us who are Catholic, the carvings are impressive with those of animals such as elephants were obviously done for a reason as explained by other TA members below.

Compare with the Anuradhapura sandakadapahana. Well worth a few photos. Very well preserved. Read the guide book about the meaning of various animals etc. I don't want to spoil your sense of discovery.

This is another key part of any tour of the wider Polonnaruwa site.  You will see a number of such semi-circular slabs, but not as clear as this one and it is helpful to have your guide explain its significance as per some of the other reviews.
Whole meaning of Buddhism summarized in one piece of stone. Every ring of the moonstone depicts a meaning. birth , life ,  desire , decay , and death
This is a beautifully elaborate and highly symbolic moonstone. The entrance to a temple literally layered with Buddhist philoshophy.

This is quite meaningful in Anuradhapura (the first kingdom). There six bands in this semi-circular slab of stone. The most outer ring is the 1st ring. Namely 1. Floral design - represents fire or our worldly life. 2. Four Beasts - Elephant, Horse, Lion and Bull.. represents (Jaathi, Jara, Wyaidhi and Marana) Bith, Decay, Diseases and the Death. 3. Intricate d foliage - Our heavy bond to the world. 4. Geese or the Swans carrying half blossomed Lotus plants (Wise men can distinguished good from the bad. 5. Less intricate d foliage - Wise men begin to see the truth and less bond to the world 6. Half Lotus - Enlightenment, Buddha or complete purification of all the actions and the thoughts. Could only be achieved by following the medium path, no any extreme ends, there are no even sins or merits to give their out comes.

It is amazing how this piece of marble contains the whole buddhism phylosophy. As you look to the different levels you are taken onto different aspects of the everyday life and buddhism. We all should learn from it

'Sandakada Pahana' (=Moonstone) is an elaborately carved semi-circular stone slab which  is normally placed at the bottom of staircases/ entrances. Out of all moonstones in Sri Lanka, the one in Polonnaruwa is the most famous and the most frequented.

This moonstone is the best one in Sri Lanka (and certainly the most well known). It's in the Polonnaruwa complex and worth a look while you are there. There are also touts selling replicas close to it that can be a bit pushy.
This is nothing other than some inscriptions on a circular stone structure. Lot of dust and sand has accumulated on this. This makes checking the inscriptions more difficult.

The moonstone or "Sandakada Pahana" is found throughout Sri Lanka in the ruined cities. It is usually places at the bottom of a flight of steps. It is a carved semi circle which evolved through the Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa and Kandy periods. Each band of carvings have a deep meaning. One theory is that it depicts the travels through "Samsara'. The outer band consists of flames; the creeper of foliage symbolises worldly desires, the lotus depicts the final achievement of Nirvana, the elephant, bull, lion and horse depict birth, decay, disease and death while the swans symbolise the distinction between good and evil. The Moonstone changes drastically throughout the difference periods, depending on the influences at the time.
